dataset.title: Black spruce seed viability from seed rain traps in the 2004 burns off the Steese, Taylor, and Dalton Highways, collected in 2005-2007.

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology; University of Saskatchewan; 112 Science Place

abstract.para: This dataset contains viability estimates of black spruce seed collected in traps at 39 intensive study sites within the 2004 burns of interior Alaska. Data are presented as raw data from trap collections at each site. All sites were in communities dominated by black spruce before burning, and were located 100 to 600 m from the road, beyond the range of any visible road effects and away from any signs of other human disturbance.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

section.title: corrections
section.para: Data were quality- and error-checked by Jill Johnstone when compiling the site-level summaries.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: The fires of 2004 burned into late August, and study sites were selected in the following spring, using three selection steps. First, we conducted an initial survey of all road-accessible portions of the three burned areas in May 2005, immediately after snowmelt. The roads we used to access the burns were the Taylor and Dalton Highways, and the Steese Highway and associated side roads. Within each burned area, we selectively identified ~30 sites (90 sites total) that encompassed the full range of fire severities, site moisture, topographic positions, and geographic dispersion that we observed in black spruce forests in each burn. We selected our sampling sites strategically to obtain maximum representation of the full range of variation in each burn, rather than by random sampling, which would have concentrated samples in the most common set of pre- and post-fire conditions. From the initial set of 90 potential sites, we used stratified selection to identify 39 sites that represented different combinations of pre-fire conditions. We randomly selected eight sites to represent each category in a factorial combination of high and low site moisture, and high and low fire severity (n=32). We also included 7 high-elevation sites to represent burned treeline forests from each area. These 39 sites were used for intensive study of post-fire seed rain.

dataTable.entityDescription: This dataset contains viability estimates of black spruce seed collected in traps at 39 intensive study sites within the 2004 burns of interior Alaska.

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique site number assigned to each plot (values are between 1 and 92).

textDomain.definition: A unique site number assigned to each plot (values are between 1 and 92).

attribute.attributeDefinition: The month and year the sample was collected in (not the date of the germination trial).

textDomain.definition: The month and year the sample was collected in (not the date of the germination trial).

attribute.attributeDefinition: An identification assigned to composite sub-samples within a site. For the first samples from Aug05, all sub-samples were pooled for the viability trial, and then tested in one (a) or two (a and b) petri dishes. For later samples, the sample ID is a listing of trap numbers included in the tested sample.

textDomain.definition: An identification assigned to composite sub-samples within a site. For the first samples from Aug05, all sub-samples were pooled for the viability trial, and then tested in one (a) or two (a and b) petri dishes. For later samples, the sample ID is a listing of trap numbers included in the tested sample.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of black spruce seeds used in the germination trial. This number may differ from the total count for that sample if subsamples were used.
The number of black spruce seeds observed to germinate in the trial.
The proportion of viable seeds in the tested seed sample.
Notes on the sample made during collection or afterward. Usually this just indicates if the sample was a coneball sample.

textDomain.definition: Notes on the sample made during collection or afterward. Usually this just indicates if the sample was a coneball sample.

otherEntity.entityDescription: A close-up photograph of the seed rain trap used for collecting spruce seeds in the 2004 burns. The trap is made from a standard plastic greenhouse tray, and is lined with Astroturf to provide a rough surface to catch seeds. Photo has been cropped in processing.

A photograph of the seed rain traps deployed in a burn in 2005, one year after burning. The traps are fixed to the ground with long nails spiked throught the bottom of the tray into the ground. Photo has been cropped in processing.
